oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Spread at Lavergne and Blue Ribbon Contest
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: A group of men, women, and children gather together for a contest or celebration of some sort.

Dr. Harry Mustard worked in Rutherford County, Tennessee, during the 1920's on behalf of the Rockefeller Foundation's Commonwealth Fund. He took photographs as part of a five-year study of health and sanitation conditions of rural children. Dr. Mustard went on to become a very prominent public health administrator. Blue Ribbon health contests provided local citizens with an opportunity and competitive incentive to practice their school health lessons.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Mustard, Harry S. (Harry Stoll), 1889-1966
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Rural health--Tennessee; Sanitation--Tennessee; Public health--Tennessee
Men; Women; Children; Picnics; Contests; Health care; Hygiene; Food
